f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:07): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, re your email subject example, good mail clients warn before sending an email without a subject because most of the time it happens, it's an accidental omission that the sender would prefer to fix

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:08): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: but the reason they prefer to fix it isn't on a spec's sayso but because they need it for communicating with the people they are seeking to communicate with
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:08): although, some insert something like (no subject) by default

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:09): experience suggests that people write bad subjects if they are new to email or if they know they are in a position of power so that recipients will want to read the email based on sender name

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:11): now the problem accessibility advocates have is that alt is for the benefit of a third party when the author seeks to communicate in images with someone who will consume the images

b9acb5df457f56156060d93d0827b8ac (12:16): FWIW, I often write bad subjects when e.g. emailing friends as the content of the mail is often just a collection of miscellany rather than one specific topic (and, honestly, I hope they would read it in any case ;) )
b9acb5df457f56156060d93d0827b8ac (12:17): Mailing lists are a different audience and so are treated differently
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:17): b9acb5df457f56156060d93d0827b8ac: I guess that falls under the case of getting read due to sender identity even if not necessarily due to a position of power

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:18): on high volume mailing lists, sometimes it's easier to read based on sender identity than based on the subject, especially when some people are known to write nonsense
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:19): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yeah. for instance, i never read your emails. ;)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:21): that's fine. I know some subscribers on some mailing lists who only read mine and a few others ;-)

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:35): what is HyTime?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:36): spaces in <img src> should be allowed
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:36): either IRIs need to be cleaned up or this concept 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e introduced but did not define should do it
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:36): HTML would have to make URI attribute values not be URIs in that case
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:37): it would just be some pre-processing
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:37): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: might slip through authoring mistakes in the form of misquoting
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:38): although now that " is not allowed in attribute names (and some other such checks), perhaps misquoted attributes would be catched anyway
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:38): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: HyTime is an ISO hypertext system based on SGML

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:40): literal space will work interoperably in attribute values of course, but not in many other URI contexts (if only because the space breaks attempts to autodetect them in text)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:40): so I don't feel too bad about that requirement
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:40): on the other hand, I think it made my html less readable to use %20
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:40): and these are relative URIs in any case
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:42): the biggest problem with spaces in href=""s that i've seen is that they risk getting wordwrapped
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:42): and then who knows what'll happen
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): http://xml.coverpages.org/hytimeKimber9701.html
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:47): look for the paragraph starting with 'Technicaly, HyTime is an "enabling architecture".'

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:54): none other than the usual "options are bad ui" thing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:54): if people want to be told when they use that syntax feature, then they should be able to obtain that information
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:54): yeah. I'm told I don't need to put it in the HTML5 UI as long as there's a magic bookmarkable URI parameter
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:56): the reasoning is that not having this feature is claimed to be an important evangelism blocker when advocating HTML5 to the XHTML-as-text/html crowd
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:57): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I threw something at it with some (unintentional) errors and it seems to me the error recovery is not yet very good
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:57): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: 'it' being Validator.nu?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:57): I forgot the close quote on some attributes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:58): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: do you mean the recovery was bad or that the messages were bad?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:58): (the recovery is per spec)

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:59): I mean that it gave lots of error messages for what was actually one mistake, and they created so much noise I could not spot my second mistake until I fixed the first
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:59): this is a UI complaint, not a standards compliance complaint

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:00): there seem to be two issues: 1) what the tokenizer spec says are errors (normative) and 2) how I phrase the errors (not normative; now phrased according to tokenization situation--not according to the probable user intent)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:00): the old behavior with < breaking out of a tag and starting a new one was more intuitive
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:02): I wonder if it were worthwhile to stop reporting errors until there has been one transition to the data state
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:03): that would seem bad for general purpose perf and for Java byte code size, though...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:04): the spec only requires that you report one error if there is one and none if there are none, right?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:05): spaces in URIs are problematic for ping= I guess
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:05): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: yeah. but on the other hand, when I opt to stop reporting errors, people complain that the parser didn't keep on trucking
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:05): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: well i just mean that you don't have to report exactly the right errors, if there are more useful ones you can report
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (13:05): does the spec require that if a conformance checker recovers from errors, it must report the same errors that the parsing algorithm would flag?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (13:06): it seems to me that for usability's sake it's probably not good for the exact set of errors reported to be a normative requirement
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:06): I'm not sure, actually. It does require recovery to be per spec
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (13:06): since quality of error messages should be a potential point of competition

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:07): Conformance checkers must report at least one parse error condition to the user if one or more parse error conditions exist in the document and must not report parse error conditions if none exist in the document. Conformance checkers may report more than one parse error condition if more than one parse error conditions exist in the document. Conformance checkers are not required to recover from parse errors.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:08): i can change the last sentence to allow arbitrary error recovery if you like

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (13:08): though in this particular case highlighting the likely actual authoring error and having the detailed error messages available in a distinguished form (indented, smaller text, disclosure triangle, something like that) would probably have been good enough
